> Is there a way to have the test suite
> abort if one of the tests fails.  in other words, if the first test in the
> list fails, then the remaining tests are not executed. In my suite() method
> I list the specific tests I want to run, rather than just returning a new
> TestSuite with the testcase class specified.


If your tests are dependant from each other, you may reconsider refactor 
them so that they can be execution in any order.

As for JUnit, unless you modify the runners, I don't think you can 
parametrize JUnit to do what you want.  If you use Ant, you have the 
"haltonfailure" option of the JUnit task but you have to check if it's 
really what you want.

general note: if you don't specify a suite() method, JUnit will 
automatically extract all your test methods from your class.  So you 
don't need to write

    public static Test suite() {
       return new TestSuite(myClass.class);

   }


> Also, I am having trouble with the Swing UI tester.  It created a
> junit.properties file to set the "loading" property to false, but it does
> not find my property file.  I specified the USER.HOME env variable as well
> as putting the file in my classpath.


The best way to figure out where JUnit looks for junit.properties file 
is to search the file on your hard drive.  JUnit searches for the 
"user.home" variable and not "USER.HOME", maybe it's the problem.
